text:
I think so much of what's happening
right now in corporate America,

and particularly with like
Silicon Valley, big tech and AI,

what we're seeing is a kind of
enclosure of data and information.

But I think there are
still market opportunities,

but ways to keep data open and free
and accessible and transparent.

I think there's
just so many sort of

untapped creative
applications of technology

that could make it so that
it could be used for justice.

And I think yes, we are entering a kind
of new or different era of transparency,

in which these citizen data science
groups are wielding data as a tool

for accountability and transparency,
and they're often highly creative.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
I'm Catherine D’Ignazio.

I'm an associate professor of
urban science and planning at MIT.

I also run a lab there,
called the Data Plus Feminism Lab,

where broadly speaking, what we do
is we try to use data and computation
to address gender and racial justice.

What does it look like to take a
feminist approach to data science?

So a feminist approach to data science
is necessary for the ways in which

we need to look at how power influences
the production of information
at every stage of the process,

from what information we even
have to how we analyze information

to what are our outputs and who do
they serve from a data science process.

And so a feminist approach,
according to myself and Lauren Klein,

who we're the co-authors of
a book called Data Feminism,

we developed seven
principles to try to say,

well, what would it look like to
make data science more feminist?

And by which we mean to make data science
work in the service of gender equality,

but also in the service of racial equality
and the service of income inequality,

and addressing social inequality
just sort of more broadly speaking.

If we take that as one of our central
things that we want data science to do,

to really do good in the world, to
rectify some of these imbalances of power,

what do we need to do to sort of
get there, and what do we need to change

about our more conventional
sort of data science practices?

And so we have seven principles,
and they're things like examine power.

So really just try to look at,
you know, again, across the pipeline,

kind of where does power
and inequality come in?

Challenge power.
Embrace pluralism.

So bring more voices to the table
in any kind of analysis process,

also in the process
of communicating data.

Make labor visible.
Rethink binaries and hierarchies.

So basically,
there's these seven things,

and in the book,
we sort of go over what do these mean,

and how would one actually
do this in practice?

So we're very much concerned about
sort of how do we introduce feminism

to data scientists, and also, how do
we introduce data science to feminists?

How do we kind of bring these
two communities together

and really start a productive dialog
around a more just data science?

So data science is predominantly male.
Is that correct?

Yes. And so yeah,
that would be absolutely true.

And in fact, as the sort of
enterprise of data science

has become more and
more prestigious,

as we've seen the rise of Big Data,
predictive analytics,

now all we're talking
 about is AI, of course;

the more kind of prestigious
these technical fields become,

the less and less gender
equality there is.

So the more and more women
and gender minorities sort of

get pushed out of these fields,
and men sort of stay at the top.

And so that is one thing that we
talk about, is sort of the narrowness

of the demographics of the folks
who are actually doing this work,

designing these technologies,
undertaking these kinds of analyses.

And that certainly is a key sort
of part of the equation for like,

bringing more people to the table for who's
actually doing the work in the first place.

What would you say are some
of your favorite moments
once the book came out in 2020?

I'm sure you had a lot of conversations
with data scientists, people in big tech.
What are some of your favorite moments?

Sure. Well, the book went
much further than we thought.

Lauren and I at the time thought we
were writing kind of this niche book.

We thought, oh, we're mostly
going to be speaking to

people who already care
about gender studies.

And the surprising thing was that there
was a real hunger for this approach.

And some of what we said
really resonated with people,

and I would say with people
that I was surprised by.

So this would be like math and statistics
teachers, for example, policymakers.

I would say we're very well embraced
by the computer science community

and the data science community,
 for the most part,

the arts and humanities
folks as well.

And so I think what we saw was like
for some folks, it was really about,

how do I bring the values I already
have into working with data,

because I haven't seen
how to do that yet.

Then for other folks, it was like,
maybe I am a professional data scientist,

but I've had a little
bit of qualms in terms of
the ways that we're working with data,

or how decontextualized
my numbers are,

or I've had doubts about, like,
are these numbers even comprehensive?

How are they collected? I don't know,
because nobody gave me the metadata.

And so for those folks, it was a kind
of giving them a language to name
some of these doubts that they had,

and then to kind of work on them
and further their own practices.

And what did you learn when you
started thinking about questions like,
can technology be used for good?

I do think technology
can be used for good.

And in fact, my whole sort of
career is premised on this idea that
we can use technology for good.

But I think again, we have to come
back to thinking very intentionally

about what is good, right?
And good for whom?

And part of that for me is recognizing
some of the current power imbalances

in technology, which start with
sort of the who's at the table,

the sort of gender, and I would
say also racial issues of like,

who's even in these server rooms like creating
these technologies in the first place?

But also all of the groups that
could potentially have technologies

designed for them, but don't necessarily,
there isn't necessarily like a market there

that's going to make a big
corporation go into that space.
I think there's just so many sort of

untapped, creative
applications of technology,

that could make it so that
it could be used for justice.

And so with that,
you started working with communities,

activists, journalists to
leverage technology and databases.
Talk to us a little bit about that.

So the Data Plus Feminism Lab,
I would say we're very much interested in

kind of this critique of kind
of the existing configuration

of resources around AI,
data science, and computation.

But at the same time, we're very interested
in modeling ways to do it differently.

So that's to say that we're not just
in the business of like throwing stones

from outside and being like, this is
bad, this is bad and this is bad.

But more in the sense of we want
to actually get down and actually

model like, how would we do
data science in a feminist way?
What problems arise in the process?

And so this is exemplified,
I think, by a recent project

that we've been working on
with activists who monitor

human rights violations,
predominantly in Latin America.

So these are activists who are
working on the topic of feminicide,

which is gender based violence that
is fatal against women and girls.

And these activists, what they do is they're
carefully tabulating from news articles.

They're trying to discover and document
cases of feminicide, and create databases.

So they're in the business of
data production, basically.
Because it's not currently tracked?
Correct.

And so this is the key thing,
is that the state, the governments

in basically all countries,
fail to actually tabulate,
keep count of these particular cases.

And this is actually true even
in countries where there are laws
about femicide and feminicide.
Okay.

So even when there's a law in the books
that says, you know, this is a crime,

or this is a kind of aggravation
of the crime of homicide,

there's not actually a systematic,
comprehensive, accurate count.

And certainly not one that is then,
like released out into the public.

And so the activists have sort of
stepped into this issue and said, well,

we will count, because our institutions
are basically failing us right now.

This is not an isolated case of like kind
of one person doing this in one place.

In fact, we have now cataloged over
200 different projects around the world

who are doing exactly this process
of like reading news articles
and trying to log cases of feminicide.

So it's an incredibly
widespread practice

of what you might call citizen
data science or data activism,

but basically folks who are
trying to keep these counts

and then use those
counts for advocacy,

for policy change,
for raising public awareness,

for reframing the problem of
feminicide in their countries.

And so this was a space where,
as we began to be in dialogue

with the activists and in
some cases journalists,

we thought, well, we have something we can
bring to the table in terms of technology.

So many of the ways that
they're going about monitoring

and capturing these
cases are very manual.

So they're literally
like loading websites,

they're checking individual web
pages of news organizations.

So we said, actually,
we can automate some part of this work.

And so we developed an AI,
basically a machine learning classifier,

that automatically is out sort
of scouting on the internet
for their particular country

looking for news stories that are
describing a case of feminicide.

It runs those through a
machine learning classifier,

and those that kind
of meet the criteria,

which the criteria actually
has been defined by activists,

then they get passed off to the
activists themselves for consideration.
Are you able to scale that?
Can a tool that is trained in Spanish

read media in other
countries in other languages?

So that's a great question.
We're working on this.
No.

So the interesting thing about this,
so we've trained a model for each language.

So we have English,
Spanish, and Portuguese.

We're currently working on a collaboration
with an organization in Kenya
in Swahili.

And so we have to train
a new model in each case.

But the other reason we have to train
a new model is not only language,

but there's actually significant
contextual differences

and different definitions
in some cases of feminicide.

And this has been very interesting
as a kind of computational issue,

because this is something where,
you know, even an activist in like,

even let's say two activists in Peru
working from two different groups,

they might not even agree with each
other on what constitutes a feminicide.

Can you give us a little
bit more context? How so?

So one kind of debate right
now in the feminicide community
is a debate around induced suicide.

When a woman commits suicide,
but it's because she's been driven

to that point by abuse from
usually an intimate partner.

And so there are feminist groups who,
they would call this a feminicide.

There is I think, one country, El Salvador,
which actually defines that legally

so that they actually have induced
suicide as a kind of a legal definition

and that would count in that
country as a feminicide.

But in other places,
people would disagree with that.

So there are these gray areas
over what constitutes a feminicide

and what does not
constitute a feminicide.

And so this was some of the
complexity, I would say,

that we had to think
about and navigate

as we were designing a machine
learning classifier, to try to say that

this news article does or does
not describe a case of feminicide.

And so what we did in these
cases was we typically

err on the side of showing the
activists more information,

and then we also leave it ultimately
up to the activists or journalists

to decide whether to
include that case.
So we present them with like,

here's what the machine
learning classifier thought,

like, here's what the system
thought, do you agree?
And it's only once they agree,

according to their definition
of feminicide in their context,

that that case gets included
into their database.

And so this was a way too to,
I would say like, value the labor,

and also the real,
I would say grounded political knowledge
of the activists themselves,

and also a way to make the AI kind of
more context sensitive, let's say,

especially when there is no one
global definition of feminicide.

So we often think
about our technologies.

You know, part of the benefit of
technology is scaling, standardization.

But this is a case in which it
doesn't make sense to standardize,

because actually the reality
is sort of fragmented.
There's like, a lot of variation.

And so this was a way we could design
it so that it would support variation

and support context,
and center the knowledge of the activists

and journalists themselves,
if that makes sense.

Can you talk to us a little bit about
the impact you've been seeing so far,
now that you're able to count this data?

The impact from counting feminicide
is really the groups themselves.

So we think about the role of
the Data Plus Feminism Lab,

and then the project
that this is a part of,

as a kind of public
interest technology project

that's in service of the activists
assembling their databases.
So we don't assemble data,

we make technologies that help
them assemble their databases.

And then what they do
with that information,

I find to be incredibly sort
of inspiring and creative.

And so on the one hand, they are often
in dialogue with government agencies.

They're writing reports,
they're pushing for policy changes

and sort of reparations for
families who've been impacted,

and in particular for
children who've been impacted.

But they also use their data in
highly creative ways to create,

for example,
physical data visualizations.

So they'll take their data over
the course of, let's say, a year,

and they'll stage these large
interventions in public spaces.

And often they're
symbolic public spaces,

so they're like the Central
Plaza in front of the Congress,

or there's one group that did
a large public intervention

outside the court for
their state in Argentina.

And they create these installations that
are, I would say very haunting;

and often this is through the use
of shoes with no people in them,
or chairs that are empty.

And so each chair, for example,
represents a person who's not with us.

And then you see through, just really
literally like the scope and scale

of the space that sort of would
have been occupied by these bodies,

you can see and I think, like,
sort of appreciate the human toll
of kind of what we have lost.

So it's a way of, I would say, staging
a kind of public dialogue about, like,

here's where we are, and like,
where do we go from here? Yeah.

Why wouldn't feminicide
cases be counted?

One of the things that's
going on right now

is we're told over and over again that
we live in this data saturated world,

that, you know,
there's all these sort of narratives

like the government knows everything,
Facebook knows everything,

you know,
Google knows everything about you.

And it sort of promotes
this false narrative that

we actually have information about
everything that's important in the world.
And in fact, that's not the case.

And we talk a lot about this concept
in Data Feminism, of missing data.

These are data that do not exist because
an institution has not collected them.

And so there's a kind
of a political demand,
by framing something as missing data

you're sort of saying these data
should exist, but they don't.

And there's a way of like,
then responsibilizing,

who is the entity that should
be collecting those data?

So for example,
in the case of feminicide,

what many of the sort of social
movements as well as kind of journalists

and public reporting
have done is to say,

“Look, we are collecting
this data about feminicide.”

But they often point the
finger at governments, and say,
“You should be doing this work.”

Many activists, actually,
when we interviewed them, they told us,

“We don't want to do this work.
Like, this is terrible work.

We're never going to be able
to do it in the same way
or at the same scale as like the state.

But we do this work because the
state is not fulfilling one of its

like most basic obligations
to the people right now,

which is to protect them
and keep them safe.”

Feminicide is a powerful
example of missing data.

But there are many other
examples of missing data,

things that one thinks we should have
information about, but in fact we don't.

So for example,
in the case of the United States,

we have this huge problem
with housing, right?

Housing insecurity, housing stability,
 housing affordability,
evictions, certainly post COVID.

And one of the things that my team
and I have discovered very intimately

is that if you want
to work on evictions,

in fact, there is no national or
federal database of evictions.

The data are collected piecemeal
by housing courts or county courts.
They are not shared.

It's often very difficult even to
obtain data for one housing court

in one jurisdiction,
for example, like Boston,

let alone if you want to try to get
a national picture of evictions.

And so I would frame, you know,
evictions as a case of missing data
in the context of the United States.

It's a sort of really pressing
social and political issue.

We kind of need insight as a way of then even
just having any kind of meaningful policy.
Are they going up or down?

You know, like just even asking like those
very basic kind of data driven questions.

But we can't ask those questions
because we don't have that information, so.

You and I had talked about some of
the implications for private sector.
Can you talk a little bit about that?

There's interesting ways in which we
can start to get a hold of these data,

which then could potentially expose
private sector to some risks.

Because one of the things that's
happening in the eviction space

and in the sort of housing
instability space right now,

is there's been a kind of an aggregation,
let's say, of housing properties.

So they've become actually part of
the portfolio of venture capitalists,
of hedge funds and things like this.

So folks are seeing housing as
a way to turn a quick profit.

There's a whole industry of 
prop tech, property technology,

that has arisen to kind of
help facilitate those things.

So like, you know, smart lock systems,
surveillance cameras that are networked

so that landlords can manage
properties, and so on.

And at the same time, some of the
most recent research shows that

the corporate landlords are actually
some of also the worst evictors.

And so there would be some
potentially risk, maybe,

in having a national
evictions database,

because what it would permit is
a kind of visibility into, like,

who of these actors is kind of
the most egregious evictor, right?

Like, who is doing serial eviction without
regard, let's say, to property rights,

or maybe they're using it as
a tool to just get people out

so they can raise the rent,
and so on and so forth.

And so there's a kind of interesting
transparency kind of function
that such a database would serve,

that would hopefully make corporate
landlords a little bit nervous, actually.

So if AI is enabling, you know,
whether it's people like you with labs

or journalists or community
activists to address missing data,

does this mean we're in
a new era of transparency
that business may not be aware of?

I think it's something to take
into account, because increasingly,

and this is a lot of what my work looks
at, is these citizen data practices.

And what's happening is that, as you know,
sort of data have become democratized,

we have relatively like,
sort of free, open tools like

Google Spreadsheets,
let's say, right,

where it becomes sort of cheaper
and cheaper, easier and easier.

You don't need that much data
literacy to compile a spreadsheet
and make some visualizations.

We see these being picked
up by these groups.

So like yes, activists and
social movements, journalists,

academic researchers,
community-based organizations,
and advocacy organizations.

And I think yes, we are entering a kind
of new or different era of transparency,

in which these citizen data
science groups are wielding data

as a tool for accountability
and transparency,
and they're often highly creative.

And I think actually the journalists
in this regard are extra creative,

because they're quite sophisticated
at understanding a particular milieu,

let's say, like a particular information
environment, and then saying,

well, who would be the entities
that would have this information?

How can I obtain that information,
and then cross reference it

with other data to tell a compelling
sort of accountability story?

I don't think we covered counter data.
Do you want to get into that?
Sure, sure.

And so counter data is like a
counterpoint to missing data.

So missing data, again,
is the data that don't exist

because our institutions
do not collect those data.

And like the feminist
side data activists,

they decided to just go forward
and they would collect the data.

And so this is an
example of counter data.

So these are data that are produced
from sort of outside of our,

what we might call our
counting institutions.

So outside of government, typically,
outside of other organizations

that are well resourced,
that typically produce data sets.

And so often, counter data are
specifically about either filling in gaps.

So in the case of missing data,
they're literally about filling in the gap;
like we have no information

so we're just going to go
ahead and collect what we can.

Or in some cases, counter data are
about challenging official information.

And so this actually also happens
in the case of feminicide.

So there are, for example in
Mexico, the federal government
does release numbers about feminicide.

They release aggregate counts, they don't
release anything more sort of detailed.

But the interesting thing about
this is that the counter data

that are produced by the activists
and journalists community

are regularly double the statistics
that the Mexican government gives.

So it's a political strategy from civil
society to challenge the official numbers,

and produce a kind of then
public discourse about, well,

what are the measurement strategies here?
What's different about this?

How are we counting differently
in these different cases?

As you look to, 
you know, all of these tools
to address the missing data, counter data,

what takeaways would you
have for business leaders?

I think so much of what's happening
right now in corporate America,

and particularly with like
Silicon Valley, big tech and AI,

what we're seeing is a kind of
enclosure of data and information.

But I think there are
still market opportunities,

but ways to keep data open and free
and accessible and transparent,

and ways to actually leverage citizen
participation in data practices.

So how do we get back to
some of these earlier ideals

around connectedness, transparency,
sharing, rather than a locking down?

So besides open data,
what else should CEOs be thinking about?

So I think the other
thing is thinking through

which parts of a kind of information
ecosystem should be privatizable,

or should be sort of proprietary
and able to be enclosed.

What is the balance of
enclosure versus commons

that we think promotes a healthy
technological future for everybody?

And I would say we are just not
investing in that commons right now,

as we think like of the
analogy of roads, right?

There is no company
that owns all the roads.
And it would be silly to think that,

because what happens is everyone
builds on top of the roads.

We put buildings on roads,
we put houses on roads.

That's the infrastructure that
allows us to do everything else.

And so that's sort of the
question that I would posit,

is how do we infrastructure
the infrastructure, right?

How do we build a collective and
healthy public digital infrastructure,

such that everyone can
build on top of it,

and not just, you know,
five corporations or something like that.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
